title: General Paper FQE (March 2022)
description: Final Qualifying Examination General Paper from March 2022. Contains 49 questions covering Nursing Education, Research, Mental Health, and Pediatrics.

questions.question: In assessing developmental milestones, a nurse should be concerned if the child does not hold head steady unsupported at:
questions.explanation: Head control is typically achieved by 3-4 months. Lack of head control by 4 months is a red flag.

questions.question: In order to 'pass' the appetite test, a child weighing 10-14.9 kgs should eat Ready to use therapeutic foods (RUTF):
questions.explanation: Guidelines state a child of this weight must consume at least half a sachet in 30 minutes to prove appetite.

questions.question: A child with a Middle Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) of 112 mm is:
questions.explanation: MUAC < 115mm (11.5cm) indicates Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). 112mm is 11.2cm.

questions.question: In management of poisoning in children:

options.text: Emesis is done as a standard procedure to reduce amount of poison ingested
Catharsis has immense benefits in improving the outcome
Excretion of certain substances can be hastened by urinary alkalinization or dialysis
Patient with Marked hypothermia or hyperthermia not responding to therapy should not be put on dialysis

questions.explanation: Urinary alkalinization helps excrete salicylates/barbiturates. Emesis is often contraindicated.

questions.question: In routine prevention of helminthiasis in children, the strategy involves:

options.text: Avoid offering universal treatment to all individuals in an area of high endemicity
Avoid offering treatment targeted to groups with high frequency of infection
Offering treatment targeted to groups with high frequency of infection, such as school children, and Improving sanitary conditions
Using human feces as fertilizer and offering individual treatment

questions.explanation: Mass drug administration (deworming) for high-risk groups combined with sanitation is the standard.

questions.question: The part of the personality that is called the rational self is:
questions.explanation: The Ego operates on the reality principle and acts as the rational decision-maker.

questions.question: In order to reduce stress for a child admitted in hospital:

options.text: Encourage parental/caregiver presence, don't allow choices
Explain procedure to child, discourage parental/caregiver presence
Allow choices where possible, encourage parental/caregiver presence
Discourage choices, explain procedure to parent/caregiver

questions.explanation: Atraumatic care principles emphasize family presence and giving the child control/choices.

questions.question: A person who collects a wallet on the road and decides to keep the money is operating on:
questions.explanation: The ID seeks immediate gratification/pleasure without regard for morality or rules.

questions.question: A child should turn towards the source of sound at:
questions.explanation: Localization of sound (turning head/eyes) begins around 3-4 months (2-3 months is the start).

questions.question: For children born of HIV positive mothers, Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis should be:

options.text: Delayed until PCR test is done

questions.explanation: Standard protocol initiates Cotrimoxazole at 6 weeks for exposed infants.

questions.question: The learning theorist that suggests that learning is for self-improvement is:
questions.explanation: Maslow (Humanism) focuses on self-actualization and self-improvement.

questions.question: Tricyclic antidepressants include:
questions.explanation: Imipramine and Amitriptyline are TCAs. Others are antipsychotics or mood stabilizers.

questions.question: Learning is encouraged in an environment that:

options.text: Encourages the cooperate rather than the personal nature of learning
Recognizes the people's right to make mistakes

questions.explanation: A safe environment allows mistakes as part of the learning process.

questions.question: When a teacher sets projects or problems, they are most likely:

options.text: Slowing down the pace of fast leaners

questions.explanation: Projects/problems are active strategies to increase motivation and relevance.

questions.question: In the psychopathology of mental illness an increase in dopamine levels will:
questions.explanation: High dopamine is associated with mania (increased activity) and schizophrenia (positive symptoms).

questions.question: The purpose of evaluation in learning is to:
questions.explanation: Evaluation measures whether objectives were met and content covered.

questions.question: A longitudinal study is a classification based on:
questions.explanation: Time dimension: Cross-sectional vs. Longitudinal.

questions.question: A type of research that aims at building knowledge but not of immediate application by practitioners is:
questions.explanation: Basic (pure) research expands knowledge without immediate application.

questions.question: A hypothesis stating 'There is no difference in performance...' is an example of:
questions.explanation: Null Hypothesis (H0) posits no relationship/difference.

questions.question: Which of the following is a source of research topic?

options.text: Lack of existence of an issue or problem relating to lives
Lack of evaluation of the effectiveness of an intervention

questions.explanation: Observing phenomena to establish patterns is a key source of research inquiry.

questions.question: Which statement is true about research questions?

options.text: Should be broader than the objectives
Should be extracted from the literature
Should relate to the variables of the study
Should go beyond the population of study

questions.explanation: Research questions must address the specific variables under investigation.

questions.question: An entire group of individuals, events or objectives having a common observable characteristic is:
questions.explanation: Population (or Target Population) refers to the entire group.

questions.question: In the Psychomotor domain of learning, the learner is expected to gain:
questions.explanation: Psychomotor = physical skills/manual dexterity.

questions.question: A psychiatric patient who displaces affection from a previous relationship to the nurse is said to be having:
questions.explanation: Transference is the patient projecting feelings onto the nurse.

questions.question: Which of the following is an absolute contra-indication of electro-convulsive therapy (ECT)?
questions.explanation: Raised ICP is the only absolute contraindication due to risk of herniation.

questions.question: In bipolar disorder, the patient with manic attack/phase presents with:

options.text: Excessive or additional to normal thoughts
Lack of sleep, loss of interest

questions.explanation: Grandiosity, flight of ideas, and indiscretions are classic manic symptoms.

questions.question: The main difference between bipolar I and Bipolar II is:

options.text: Bipolar I has manic episodes; Bipolar II has only depressive episodes
Bipolar I has manic episodes; Bipolar II has depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes
Bipolar I has depressive episodes; Bipolar II has manic episodes
Bipolar I has manic episodes; Bipolar II has depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes

questions.explanation: Bipolar I involves full Mania. Bipolar II involves Major Depression + Hypomania.

questions.question: In preparation of a handout:

options.text: Ensure statements are consistent with other texts that the learner uses
Do not use major and minor headings
Avoid questions and exercises within the text

questions.explanation: Consistency with other materials prevents confusion.

questions.question: In problem based learning, the learner should:

options.text: Carry out analysis and synthesis of the whole learning process

questions.explanation: PBL requires the learner to actively analyze and synthesize information.

questions.question: A sampling design that involves identifying initial subjects who then refer others is:
questions.explanation: Snowball sampling is based on referrals.

questions.question: A disorder characterized by the expression of an emotional conflict through the development of physical symptoms is called:
questions.explanation: Conversion disorder involves physical symptoms (often neurological) without medical cause, linked to psychological conflict.

questions.question: In a child with a chronic disorder, the family should:

options.text: Adjust the family routine to fit child's care needs
Maintain family routine and modify child's treatment needs
Keep the child in hospital as much as possible

questions.explanation: Maintaining normalcy is key. Care should fit into the family routine, not disrupt it entirely.

questions.question: The fear of closed places is:
questions.explanation: Claustrophobia is fear of enclosed spaces.

questions.question: Atypical antipsychotics:

options.text: Are more likely to cause hypotension
Are more likely to cause weight gain

questions.explanation: Atypicals (2nd gen) cause metabolic syndrome and weight gain more often than typicals.

questions.question: A patient brought to the hospital by a police officer against their will is admitted as:
questions.explanation: Admission without consent is Involuntary.

questions.question: Assigning participants to a control or experimental group on a random basis is called:
questions.explanation: Randomization involves random assignment.

questions.question: Researcher ratings influenced by initial impression is called:
questions.explanation: Halo effect is bias based on initial positive/negative impressions.

questions.question: An infant with poor weight gain, tachypnoea, tachycardia and cyanosis likely has:
questions.explanation: These are classic signs of cardiac failure/cyanotic heart disease.

questions.question: Qualitative data can be:

options.text: In form of words and text

questions.explanation: Qualitative data is narrative (words/text).

questions.question: When a nurse asks 'do you think you need treatment?', they are assessing:
questions.explanation: Insight refers to awareness of illness and need for help.

questions.question: Explain three (3) purposes of literature review in research.
Explain two differences between qualitative and quantitative studies.
Outline five (5) psychological effects of excessive alcohol consumption.
State five (5) functions of the Kenya Board of Mental Health.
Explain the three (3) domains of learning as per Bloom's taxonomy.
Explain two (2) general danger signs assessed in IMCI.
Explain three (3) components of a lesson plan.
State four (4) ethical issues in research that concern the respondents.
Case Study: Master A (10yo) admitted with Nephrotic Syndrome. Select correct symptoms and management.

options.text: Management: Low Salt, High Calorie Diet
